article.title: A Cascade Architecture for Keyword Spotting on Mobile Devices

multiple_choice_question.text: Which component of the cascade architecture is responsible for continuously listening for the keyword?
choices: Server
Application Processor - Stage 2 Keyword Spotter
Always-on DSP - Stage 1 Keyword Spotter
Speaker Verification module

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the "Speaker Verification" module in the cascade architecture?
choices: To ensure that only authorized speakers can trigger the keyword.
To enhance the accuracy of the keyword spotting by filtering out background noise.
To compress the audio signal before processing it on the server.
To perform speech recognition and convert the spoken keyword into text.

multiple_choice_question.text: Where does the final decision on keyword detection occur?
choices: Always-on DSP
Microphone
Server
Application Processor

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of using a cascade architecture for keyword spotting?
choices: It reduces the need for speaker verification.
It eliminates the need for server-side processing.
It balances accuracy with low power consumption by using a smaller, less accurate first stage.
It allows for the use of larger, more complex models on the Always-on DSP.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the variable *h(y)* represent in Formula (1)?
choices: The smoothed posterior values of the acoustic units.
The final score for the presence of the keyword, ranging from 0 to 1.
The maximum value of the smoothed posteriors within the sliding window.
The length of the sliding window used for smoothing.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Table 1, what is the impact of increasing the stage 1 FA/hr (False Accept rate per hour) on the cascade\'s overall FRR (False Reject Rate)?
choices: It significantly increases the cascade\'s FRR.
It slightly decreases the cascade\'s FRR.
It has no impact on the cascade\'s FRR.
It makes the cascade\'s FRR unstable and unpredictable.
